title: Dr Michael Mosley for the Daily Mail
text: DR MICHAEL MOSLEY: Last week, I had a great time watching documentaries that celebrated the 50th anniversary of the first man to walk on the Moon (pictured, the moon landing). I remember the event happening live on television and thinking how thrilling it was to see people for the first time on another world. It seemed to me, aged 12 and a nerdy scientist-to-be, that this was a perfect triumph of the human spirit, as well as a remarkable feat of technology. My older brother, who likes a good argument, said he thought the whole thing was a waste of time and money. It was true, I admitted, that the cost of getting those men to the Moon was enormous. But there were also lots of tremendous benefits to the space race, I countered, such as the invention of the non-stick frying pan. Except, of course, I now know this is a myth. ...read
